English.lblWhatWasRevolutionAns:
The Romanian Revolution was very quick and filled
with confusion, and it only lasted for seven days. Most
of the country did not even know a revolution was 
happening until after it was over. The revolution occured
in 1989 and many Romanians continue to feel nostalgic
towards communism.
English.lblWorkAnsPolLong: Jobs were limited: Securitate, engineer, doctor, professor, factory worker, or, if skilled, a sportsman. Family pressure pushed for roles like lawyer, doctor, or pilot. Assignments were far from home, often in villages in the middle of nowhere, with no choice or prior knowledge of the destination.
English.lblWorkAns: "Who knows where in the country, but you had the job. Let's presume you finished medicine. You became a young doctor, but who knows where in a little village in Romania."
English.lblUniversityAnsPolLong: University was mostly for students to obtain technical degress that would help in industrialization, construction, education, and health. After graduating, they were sent to anywhere in the country where there was a need for 'repartisare.' University was especially attractive to young men because they could shorten their mandatory military service.
English.lblUniversityAns: "After finishing my studies, I would have been sent to go as a teacher somewhere in the countryside for a compulsatory partisanship."
English.lblUniversityQ: Why did people choose to go to university?
English.lblEmigrationAnsPolLong: Emigration was nearly impossible and trying to escape the country was met with rejection, arrest, and imprisonment. You could only leave if you were a sportsman or had special permission. You were forced to provide information upon your return.
English.lblEmigrationAns: "I became very attractive as a German-speaking student for the Securitate… they needed a translator to accompany a young secretary of the central committee of the young communists. One of their bosses got invited to a conference in West Germany and they selected me to be a translator... they were testing me. I then defected."
English.lblEmigrationQ: What was the punishment for trying to leave Romania?
English.lblYouthOrgAnsPolLong: Pioneers are a ranking in schools from 2nd-8th grade, which was indicated by wearing a red scarf. Many school children fought over having a rank in school because it gave more value to their lives.
English.lblYouthOrgQ: What did being a pioneer in grade school mean?
English.lblDemonstationAnsPolLong: Civilians were forced to attend Communist party festivities that promoted comunist ideologies and praising Nicolae Ceausescu. Consequences for not attending could include being fired from your job or harsh torture.
English.lblDemonstationAns: "You were not supposed to understand why, you were just obliged to do it. This way, they manipulated you to lose your inner self and become a part of collectivity."
English.lblMediaAnsPolLong: Books, movies, and news were available but all were censored to control information and prevent criticism of the regime. The role of the media was to spread state propaganda, convincing people that Ceausescu was a great leader and that life was better than it really was. Some Romanian and foreign media was sold in black markets.
English.lblMediaAns: "We didn't have TV, you know. It was only for two hours during the evening when the whole program was only about Ceausescu. It was nothing else."
English.lblMediaQ: What type of media was available?
English.lblRationAnsPolLong: Rations = fixed amount of goods that citizens are allowed to consume in times of shortages. Rations were placed on basic necessities like food, cooking oil, soaps, gasoline, electricity, and heating.
English.lblRationAns: "We have to deal with rations, because if we want to buy usual stuff like oil or gas or bread or meat or butter, we have to have the cards, the tickets for the rations."
English.lblChildhoodAnsPolLong: Many were protected by their parents but some still knew that the propaganda was lies. Children had to do chores, wait in the ration queues, and do homework in the dark. But, they still had hobbies and played with their friends. Some children lost their mothers due to illegal failed abortions.
English.lblChildhoodAns: "Parents fought to create some sense of normalcy in the midst of the disaster that was reality."
English.lblChildhoodQ: What was it like to be a child during this period?
English.lblFoodAnsPolLong: Food was scarce and there was no variety in stores. Basic necessities were rationed and of much worse quality compared to today.
English.lblFoodAns: "We have to deal with rations, because if we want to buy usual stuff like oil or gas or bread or meat or butter, we have to have the cards, the tickets for the rations."
English.lblSchoolAnsPolLong: School was very strict. The party wanted to demonstrate how educated and proper its citizens were - kids were even required to write in ink in a calligraphy style. All classrooms had a portrait of Ceausescu and students had to chant slogans about the Romanian Communist Party and how great Ceausescu is every day. There were lessons about the communist ideology and students were punished for not being able to recite Ceausescu's policies and speeches.
English.lblSchoolQ: How was learning in school different in this time?
